Thunder Stopwatch is a simple timer that estimates the distance to a flash of lightning.

Thunderstorms are dangerous! Nothing replaces your own common sense. The author takes no liability for potentially dangerous actions performed while using this application, including but not limited to standing out in a thunderstorm while using a phone. Be safe!
Send an email for app support.

Press the button to start the timer when you see a flash of lighting. Press the button again to stop the timer when you hear the corresponding sound of thunder.

Light travels extremely fast (186,000 mi/s) so we see lightning almost immediately, but the sound of thunder is a wave of vibrating air molecules that travels through the atmosphere at a much slower speed. The exact speed of sound varies depending on temperature and humidity but an approximate speed is one mile every five seconds (or one kilometer every three seconds).

Remember that speed = distance / time. We know the approximate speed of sound (1/5 mi/s) and we know how long it took the sound to reach us (in seconds) so we can determine the distance by rearranging the equation.


	speed = distance / time
 	distance = speed * time


	distance (in mi) = 1/5 mi/s * time (in seconds)
 	distance (in mi) = time (in seconds) / 5


	distance (in km) = 1/3 km/s * time (in seconds)
 	distance (in km) = time (in seconds) / 3


The next time you want to know how far away a lightning strike was, count how many seconds it takes the thunder to reach you, then divide by 5 (or 3).

For example if it takes thunder 10s to reach you, the lightning strike was 2 miles away. If you can see lightning but cannot hear thunder then the strike was probably more than 10 miles away.

Thunder StopWatch performs this simple calculation using a slightly more accurate (but still approximate) speed of sound.

The NOAA advises that no place outside is safe when thunderstorms are in the area. If you can hear thunder then lightning is close enough to strike.
 
Seek shelter in a substantial structure and remain there until after the threat has passed. Stay off electrical equipment like the phone or computer and avoid plumbing like sinks and bathtubs. Do not lie or lean against concrete floors or walls and avoid windows and exterior doors.
 
If you cannot get indoors then avoid elevated areas like hills, ridges and peaks. Avoid objects that conduct electricity such as power lines or metal fences. Immediately get out and away from bodies of water like lakes and ponds. NEVER seek shelter under a large tree, a cliff, or a rock overhang, and NEVER lie flat on the ground. If at all possible take shelter in a nearby vehicle or building.
 
If someone is struck they may need immediate medical attention. DO NOT WAIT to approach - victims do not carry an electrical charge. Call for help and administer CPR or AED as necessary.

The NOAA provides a number of public service announcements for lightning safety:
